chapter.title: SQL Queries
chapter.para: In the previous chapter we formed queries based on JPAQL -- which are based on entity and property names and the relationships defined within the entity class structure. In a real application, there is also a need to form queries that go outside the boundaries of the entity class model -- but should still be pushed to the database to perform. JPA provides us an escape hatch to execute raw SQL queries.

section.title: Setup
section.para: In this section you will setup a JUnit test case to do work within this chapter.

listitem.para: Create a JUnit test case in src/test called SQLQueryTest. Have this class extend QueryBase. Create an initial test method to verify the setup/teardown works correctly.
Build the module and run the test case.
listitem.programlisting:
$ mvn clean test -P\!h2db -Ph2srv -Dtest=myorg.queryex.SQLQueryTest ... Tests run: 1, Failures: 0, Errors: 0, Skipped: 0
[INFO] ------------------------------------------------------------------------ [INFO] BUILD SUCCESS

listitem.para: You may remove the sample @Test at this time since we will be adding more below.

section.title: Create/Execute SQL Query
section.para: In this section you will create a SQL Query using the entity manager. The SQL Query need not have any relation to do with the actual entity model.

listitem.para: Add the following test method to your JUnit test case. This test case will form a native SQL query, have it executed by the entity manager, and be provided with its results. There is no need to open/close SQL Connections, create/close SQL Statements, or work with SQL ResultSets. The results are provided in a List for getResultList() or a value in getSingleResult() that we must cast to the appropriate type.
Run the new test method and observe the database query that resulted.
listitem.programlisting: $ mvn clean test -P\!h2db -Ph2srv -Dtest=myorg.queryex.SQLQueryTest#testSQLQuery ... -*** testSQLQuery *** Hibernate: select title from queryex_movie order by title ASC -Animal House -Apollo 13 -Diner -Footloose -Sleepers -Tremors -Wag The Dog ... [INFO] BUILD SUCCESS
listitem.para: Notice the query issued to the database is exactly what you entered.

section.para: You have completed issuing a native SQL query using the entity manager. Native SQL queries support many of the same features as JPAQL queries
SQL Queries, however, will never return a managed entity. The next section shows a nice feature where you can defined a result class to encapsulate the values returned from the query.

section.title: SQL Query Result Mapping
section.para: Since JPAQL queries can only be expressed in terms of the entity model, there may be times when a more complicated native SQL query is required to obtain the entities you wish to work with. In this section you will use the simplest form of this capability -- where nothing additional is needed except the specification of the entity. We can use this form when the result returns a single entity class.

listitem.para: Add the following test method to your existing JUnit test case. We will assume that one needed to express a very complicated native SQL command to derive the entities desired. However, once identified, the query must return all columns defined in the default entity mapping.
The native SQL query is free to do whatever it takes to identify the entity of interest
The native SQL query is required to supply all columns required by the entity

listitem.programlisting: $ mvn clean test -P\!h2db -Ph2srv -Dtest=myorg.queryex.SQLQueryTest#testSQLResultMapping -*** testSQLResultMapping *** Hibernate: select m.* from queryex_movie m join queryex_director dir on dir.person_id = m.director_id join queryex_person p on p.id = dir.person_id where p.first_name = 'Ron' order by title ASC -result=[Apollo 13 (1995), Tremors (1990)] -em.contains(Apollo 13 (1995))=true -em.contains(Tremors (1990))=true ... [INFO] BUILD SUCCESS
listitem.para: Notice the query executes whatever is in the native SQL and returns the columns required by the default entity mapping. The returned entity instances are managed by the persistence context -- any changes to these entities will cause a database update.
